stream_context.summary: Kaze continues a long refactor of the decompiled Mario 64 codebase while finishing an overworld quest involving giant crabs bullying koi fish. He implements the quest’s spawning/behavior logic, fixes crashes, and prototypes how the koi will hint at a hidden side-level entrance via circling a new “hugging Yoshi” statue. He also outlines plans for progress-dependent Yoshi NPC dialogue trees, discusses emulator/hardware support targets, and raises the need for deterministic RNG options for speedrunners.
stream_context.significance_reason: He treats the crab/koi overworld mission as essentially complete (with a noted cutscene bug), ties it directly to unlocking Marty’s large side level, and reports beta testing for the first 10 courses is largely finished while refactoring nears completion (~80–90%).

findings.summary: Kaze reports a multi-week refactor pass across the Mario 64 codebase is nearing completion (roughly 80–90%), with the remaining work focused on late-stage systems like SoundInit; he views the refactor as yielding simpler, more straightforward code and numerous small improvements.

Beta testing for the first 10 courses is largely complete, with two exceptions still being reworked by Biobak and requiring additional testing; Kaze is currently re-testing Course 11 and expects Course 12 to need substantial testing/quality work.

Overworld quest flow is clarified: at ~55 stars, three giant crabs spawn in the river and push koi fish outward; the player ground-pounds the crabs to drive them away, freeing the koi and earning a star.

After the koi are freed, they become an environmental hint system: they swim in circles around a new central landmark (a statue of two Yoshis hugging) and the player is expected to follow them to trigger an overworld gate/entrance opening to a hidden side level.

Kaze iterates on hint readability: three laps around a large area felt too long/unclear, so he considers fewer laps and/or a smaller, more striking circle target (the statue), and discusses adding a visual cue like a whirlpool, world shake, or other feedback when the unlock triggers.

He resolves multiple implementation issues in the koi/crab system: crabs were not spawning because the related star had already been collected; fish placement/rotation required correct face angle handling; and a crash was traced to a C switch/case variable declaration leading to a null pointer—prompting a code restructure.

Kaze identifies and works around engine/cutscene constraints: NPC-dialog actions can’t run while Mario is in water, so he considers using time-stop-style cutscene handling as a more general solution for water-adjacent cutscenes.

A specific bug is recorded: the water star collection cutscene does not end (Mario can’t move when the camera focuses on his face). He also notes needing to set/OR the correct star flags to prevent unintended warp-out behavior after star collection in this context.

Marty’s side level is described as a large non-course area (Japanese garden with a wizard), possibly the biggest side level in the project; the koi/statue circling mechanic is directly used as the overworld unlock pathway to Marty’s entrance/gate.

Platform support priorities are explicit: Kaze targets real Nintendo 64 hardware and Project64 with GlideN64 as his two required baselines; other emulators are “nice bonus,” and if they fail he frames it as an emulator bug to be fixed (with specific annoyance at Ares’s flicker/button issues and Parallel Launcher updates breaking compatibility).

RNG is currently non-deterministic (potentially influenced by external factors), but Kaze considers adding an optional speedrunner-facing button combo at boot that would force determinism by sweeping/initializing memory, enabling consistent outcomes for competitive runs.

Kaze describes a practical production constraint: he prefers to secure sponsors for videos to cover editing costs; without a sponsor, releasing certain videos can be financially negative, and he’s struggling to find sponsorship for a video about a guns/trucks-themed game concept.

biobak.summary: Two of the first 10 courses remain in rework from Biobak and need additional test passes; preliminary testing is already done, implying Biobak’s changes are close to ready but not final.

findings.summary: Marty is actively building a major side level (Japanese garden with a wizard). Kaze designs the overworld koi/crab quest and statue-circling hint to open a gate leading directly to Marty’s level, and tells Marty the entrance has been updated/finished enough to show.
Kaze reiterates hope that Saren can help rework audio/sound-engine aspects, specifically mentioning the idea of a royalty-free version that would benefit from sound engine changes.

A discussion with Saren touches on a “no-OS”/direct-hardware-access approach (K0/K1, fewer protections/overheads). Kaze is interested but notes he still needs threading and thus context save/restore, and he is waiting to evaluate related work before committing.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: If another emulator doesn't run it, that's a nice bonus, but I don't consider that a necessity. If another emulator doesn't run it, then I say fix the emulator.
memorable_quotes.context: His compatibility philosophy: real N64 + PJ64/GlideN64 are the hard targets; everything else is secondary.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I always start off with the most offensive version of a concept, and then we slowly turn the offensiveness down.
memorable_quotes.context: How he prototypes puzzles/hints: start with minimal guidance, then add hints if players can’t infer the solution.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Every time someone asks, I add an extra day. We are now in 2035.
memorable_quotes.context: A recurring release-pressure joke that also signals long timelines and scope creep.

key_stories.title: Overworld crab quest becomes a gate to a major side level
key_stories.summary: Kaze finishes the logic for an overworld event where giant crabs block koi fish until the player defeats them, earning a star. He then turns the freed koi into a diegetic hint system, circling a new hugging-Yoshi statue to guide the player toward opening a gate to Marty’s large Japanese-garden side level.
key_stories.challenge: Create an overworld quest that feels alive (NPC-like fish behavior), rewards the player, and meaningfully unlocks optional content without relying on explicit UI markers.
key_stories.process: Implement crab spawn gating by star progress (~55 stars), fix missing spawns due to already-collected stars, debug fish placement/rotation and a crash caused by a C switch/case variable scope issue, and iterate on the hint design (laps, circle radius, statue as focal object).
key_stories.outcome: Quest is considered functionally done with remaining polish items (camera focus for the unlock cutscene, a bug where the water star cutscene doesn’t end, and improved feedback like a whirlpool).

key_stories.title: Refactor sprint to stabilize a growing decomp-based game
key_stories.summary: Kaze describes weeks of refactoring across the codebase, nearing completion and yielding simpler, clearer systems. This refactor is framed as ongoing foundational work enabling faster iteration and fewer mysterious bugs as the project scales.
key_stories.challenge: A Mario 64 decomp hack grows into a full game, making legacy/modified code hard to maintain and debug.
key_stories.process: Systematically refactor file-by-file (nearing SoundInit), incorporating small improvements found along the way; defer some audio-related refactors in hopes of team support.
key_stories.outcome: Refactor is ~80–90% complete; Kaze expects roughly another week or two to finish, and sees it as a prerequisite for efficient development.

key_stories.title: Cutscenes and NPC logic collide with water mechanics
key_stories.summary: While building the koi unlock event, Kaze discovers his NPC dialog action state can’t be used while Mario is swimming. He pivots toward time-stop-based cutscene handling as a more robust pattern for events that can trigger in water.
key_stories.challenge: Trigger a readable unlock/cutscene in an area where the player is often swimming, without breaking Mario’s action state logic.
key_stories.process: Trace the failure to dialog code setting Mario into a reading action; explore alternatives and decide time stop is likely the simplest generalized fix.
key_stories.outcome: A new approach is chosen, but implementation/polish remains (including the bugged water star cutscene end state).

open_questions.topic: Final design of the koi ‘circle to unlock’ hint and feedback
open_questions.context: Kaze is uncertain how many laps/circles are readable and fun, and considers adding a whirlpool or world shake to signal the unlock; he also worries about fish clipping into the statue.
questions: What exact player action should count (full laps, time spent near the statue, matching fish angle progress, or simply ‘swim with them’)?
What’s the target number of laps now (2, 3, or something dynamic), and why?
What visual/audio feedback will confirm progress (whirlpool, statue rotation, camera cut, rumble, sound cue), and how will it avoid looking like a bug?
Should the secret be discoverable before freeing the fish (accidental early unlock) to reward exploration, and how does that affect narrative logic?

open_questions.topic: Water star collection cutscene not ending
open_questions.context: Kaze notes the “water star collection cutscene doesn’t seem to end,” leaving Mario stuck when the camera focuses on his face; he also mentions star flags/OR logic to prevent warping.
questions: What is the intended post-star behavior in overworld missions—no warp, quick regain control, or a custom cutscene?
Is the hang caused by an action state mismatch, camera script, or time-stop logic, and how will he regression-test similar events?
Does the save system’s ‘last selected star’ interaction contribute to the stuck state or camera behavior?

open_questions.topic: Progress-dependent Yoshi NPC dialogue system (‘dialogue trees’)
open_questions.context: Kaze wants Yoshis to display different text based on progress (stars, events, EP ROM bits). He sketches a node/leaf structure with conditional jumps but finds current Yoshi talk code “incorrigible” and considers rewriting it.
questions: What data source is the canonical ‘progress state’ (EP ROM bits, star count, event flags), and how are these bits authored and maintained?
Will the dialogue system be authored by designers/writers via a tool, a data table, or hardcoded structs/macros?
How will he keep dialogue logic maintainable across many NPCs without copy-paste, and what are the minimum features needed (conditions, priorities, fallbacks)?
What’s the plan for differentiating ‘Yoshi with purpose’ vs ‘no-purpose’ Yoshis, and will those become quest-givers later?

open_questions.topic: Audio refactor and the ‘royalty-free version’ goal
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions the sound engine ideally needs rework if they want a royalty-free version, and he hopes Saren can help (but doesn’t assume it).
questions: What specifically makes the current audio pipeline non-royalty-free (samples, sequences, original game assets, tooling constraints)?
What scope of sound-engine changes are required: replacement assets only, or engine-level behavior changes as well?
If Saren can’t take it on, what’s Kaze’s fallback plan and timeline?

open_questions.topic: Deterministic mode for speedrunning vs non-deterministic RNG
open_questions.context: Kaze says RNG is currently non-deterministic and even external factors like temperature could influence it; he considers a boot-time button combo that sweeps memory to force determinism.
questions: What gameplay systems currently depend on RNG (spawns, movement variation, particle effects), and which ones must be deterministic for fair speedruns?
How exactly would the boot combo enforce determinism (memory init, fixed seed, disabling hardware jitter sources), and would it alter performance or loading?
Would deterministic mode be an officially supported speedrun category setting (displayed on file select or HUD)?
